reviewText: While some of the special effects shots are poor and the script is not the best, the aircraft used in the film are spectacular. The biplanes, not the type you are used to in WWI aviation films  are used  are period correct because they were still relatively modern when the film was done and a few of the real operating aircraft scenes are outstanding. Filmed at a time open cockpit biplanes were still "cool" you get to fly along and the tension is real and there is one scene where you realize that although technology changes, people and corporate bureaucracy do not.  There are heroes and those that use heroes as a means to an end. The film engages dramatically as you are increasingly at the edge of your seat as the suspense increases and you realize that at one time, flying was really like this.  Gable is only a part of the cast, and the film is respectful, there is no fake heroism here.  Even if you are familiar with the book, you will enjoy the film and it's unpredictable outcome. Highly recommended and you even see one of the techniques of starting large aircraft in this period.  One of the better aviation films made.
summary: A MUST for Early Aviation Buffs

reviewText: Warner Archive Collection is releasing the first MGM "Night Flight(1933)" DVD, although a "grey-market" VHS copy has been available for several years. "Night Flight" was withdrawn from circulation in 1942 due to a rights issue. A joy and a disappointment, "Night Flight" is based on Antoine de Saint-Exupery's best seller about South American airmail pioneers in the early 20th century. John Barrymore stars as A. Riviere, managing director of Trans_Andean Mail Service. Riviere is ruthless in ensuring the timely delivery of the mails. He demands that pilots deliver their cargo at any cost; despite any danger. One pilot must deliver a precious vaccine to the infantile paralysis unit at the City Hospital in Rio de Janeiro, before one child, one special child, dies...John and Lionel Barrymore dominate "Night Flight". It was the fifth and final MGM pairing of the famous brothers, and sadly, their weakest film together. Robert Montgomery appears in two or three scenes. Clark Gable is seen in just one sequence, in the cockpit of his plane. Helen Hayes, as his adoring wife, has no scenes with him at all. Myrna Loy, now a success after appearing with John in "Topaze", is in one scene. Dont' blink. You'll miss her. "Night Flight" is disjointed, with some sequences stilted and theatrical, as director Clarence Brown uses "wipes" to segue from one aerial shot to another. There are some good shots of aircraft during a night-time voyage(done with miniatures) and a well-done storm scene. But the movie creaks in a Hollywood ending with "ghost pilots" emerging from the sea and floating up to heaven. During production, John Barrymore was called in to producer David O. Selznick's office for not knowing his lines. He had been drinking. In 1932, Irving Thalberg had offered John a contract for $110,000, starting at $3500 a week. But "Night Flight" fared poorly with critics and film-goers. John Barrymore's contract was not renewed. Thalberg told Spencer Berger at the time: "It was one of our hardest decisions". After "Night Flight", John Barrymore had a few good parts in a few good films, but generally he starred in low-budget B-Pictures. "Night Flight" DVD extras include "Swing High", a vintage sports series short subject, a classic cartoon, "When the Cat's Away", and a trailer. The real problem with "Night Flight" is it's star. Once classical actor John Barrymore is haughty and nervous; he chain-smokes and barks through every scene. In December, 1933's Vanity Fair, Pare Lorentz explained: "Mr. Barrymore growled when he should have whispered".

reviewText: ... but interesting and worthwhile just the same. Actually I'd give this one about 3.5/5 stars. MGM gives this story of early forays into night flight in South America the star treatment, but unfortunately we don't get to see most of these stars do what they do best - interact with one another. John Barrymore, as head of the night flight operation, spends most of his time robotically barking out orders or reproaches. Lionel Barrymore, as the inspector who gets no respect, is very good here, gets quite a bit of screen time, and winds up having a prolonged and interesting scene with Robert Montgomery who plays a young pilot.Helen Hayes, whose most famous film role as Madelon Claudet is no doubt destined to be ignomiously dumped onto DVD-R via the Warner Archive, has lots of screen time here as the wife of a pilot (Jules - played by Clark Gable) who is waiting on her husband to return from his first night flight for a late night celebration supper. As his arrival is delayed more and more throughout the night, so grows her panic.The oddest thing here is the misuse - or should I say lack of use - of Clark Gable. Throughout the film he is stuck in a plane, mute and motionless. Except for a few log entries that he makes and some of his facial expressions we are really denied a performance here or for that matter, an idea of what is going through his mind.I'd say it's worthwhile just because it's such an odd departure from what MGM generally did in the 1930's plus it's been locked in the vaults for 75 years due to rights problems. It's interesting to see how Warner Home Video has taken almost a film school approach to what they put out on DVD in the last couple of years. Practically all of their documentaries on film history wind up on pressed DVD, but some pretty entertaining precodes, noirs, and even more modern films such as "Don't Be Afraid of the Dark" wind up in the Warner Archive on DVD-R, a medium that doesn't usually have a life span greater than a couple of years.
summary: Certainly not Grand Hotel in the clouds....

reviewText: I received this for Christmas and watched it once. I just had a second go around as I watched this as a tv premiere on cable giant TCM.Here is a little background on this film. Based on a book by Antoine Saint Exupery, this film was first seen in 1933 and after its first showing never surfaced again either in theaters or on television. The author didn't like the film and exercised a legal right to not have this shown again which apparently resulted in a legal limbo that lasted for almost 80 years. Ironic as Saint Exupery and virtually all the other people involved with this film have been dead for decades.Done in the grand MGM style of Grand Hotel, Dinner At Eight, and David Copperfield which included an all star cast, this movie is good but definitely suffers when compared with the previously mentioned blockbusters. On a second viewing, the deficiencies in the film are more apparent.The premise is to tell the story of the development of a certain aspect of flight, this movie hones in on the inauguration of night flights in South America. These were not passenger flights, but they served the purpose of linking several major regions of South America with multiple flights converging in one place to meet boats going to Europe and presumably other places to deliver. In 2012 this doesn't sound like much, but the planes flown were very primitive. Usually they were two seaters with no cabin. The pilots only physical protection were heavy suits, hats, and boots and radio transmission. The routes taken were dangerous traversing the Andes and the open sea and undesirable conditions such as bad weather, heavy winds, and fog.This story is told over a period of 24 hours. It covers the routes of all the pilots, overseen by the operating director of the airline (John Barrymore) and his underling played by Lionel Barrymore. The pilots are Clark Gable, Robert Montgomery, and Edward Gargan. The women they leave behind are Helen Hayes, Dorothy Burgess, and Myrna Loy. The problem with the way the characters are developed is that they are often sort of flat and predictable. The action moves quickly and the aerial photography is the thing that makes this film memorable, but the acting is just o.k. Frankly, they might have been better off dumping the human interaction aspect to this movie.The big plus that this particular Night Flight offers is an interesting story about pioneering flight, great visual sequences, and harrowing and tense moments. The negatives are somewhat flat characterizations that are overall unsatisfying and lacking emotion, with only Helen Hayes doing adequate hanky wringing.This is a remarkably clean film that has great photography including aerial sequences that must have been difficult to achieve, interesting transitional shots, and a few really frightening moments.Alas, I liked this film but didn't love it despite its stellar cast.

reviewText: Ok, it's true that the major companies (such as MGM, Warner Home Video, Sony) have been winding down their DVD offerings. The great days of remastered DVD editions of restored classics are no more, so it was a great surprise when Warner Home Video decided to release the long-unavailable NIGHT FLIGHT in this excellent DVD package, complete with a vintage short and a cartoon. The film is a fine example of MGM's all-star entertainments from the early 1930s, this one with John and Lionel Barrymore, Helen Hayes, Clark Gable, Robert Montgomery, Myrna Loy (though William Gargan isn't prominently billed, he does have a major part). The drama is fairly well developed, the flying sequences are truly spectacular, and the stars show why they're stars. Clarence Brown was one of the stalwarts of MGM's directors (he would be the director who worked with Greta Garbo the most), and he does his usual excellent job in keeping this all-star vehicle flying. All in all, a fine package, and certainly recommended now that DVDs are no longer much in production.

reviewText: For no very good reason, someone at MGM decided that Antoine de Saint-Exupery's bestseller about running mail by air across the South American continent (based on his own experiences) would make a great all-star film along the lines of GRAND HOTEL the year before: both Barrymores are here again (John as Riviere, the splenetic boss of the transcontinetal mail operation, with Lionel as his whining flunky), and so too as aviators are Robert Montgomery and Clark Gable (the latter in a part that is practically non-speaking), and also with Helen Hayes as Gable's adoring wife and Myrna Loy as another pilot's wife (she is billed simply as "Wife of the Brazilian Pilot" even though her name was plastered all over the posters advertising the movie with the other stars). There's lots of tedious melodrama, most of which involves either Hayes making fussy preparations for a private dinner with Gable once he delivers his mail or John Barrymore arching his eyebrows and expostulating in front of a 20-foot tall lighted map of South America in his office which lets the audience know where the mail planes are as the plot progresses.The stuff of real interest is what lies in between: the spectacular footage of small planes flying through storm and fog and between mountains (they couldn't fly above them at the time because of technological limitations) to bring the mail to Buenos Aires. The influence of the German Bergenfilms so popular at the time is quite evident here, and the aerial footage is astonishing, and makes it possible to tolerate the all-star dramatics. Loy fares the best here, despite the smallness of her part; she genuinely brings some conviction to her short speech, while Hayes emotes all over the place in her much larger and showier role. Lionel Barrymore's part is so unremarkable that much has to be made of his character's eczema to give him something to do so as to eat up the time between shots of Montgomery zipping through the Andes or of Gable and his co-pilot hurtling through a storm. None of the characters seems to do much to convince us they are either French or South American; the second movement of Beethoven's 7th Symphony thunders in the background, again for no very good reason other than that it makes everything all the more dramatic. The film all but vanished for decades after MGM lost the rights to Saint-Exupery's material in the early 40s.

reviewText: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) presents "NIGHT FLIGHT" (1933) (84 min/B&W;) -- Starring: John Barrymore, Helen Hayes, Clark Gable, Lionel Barrymore, Robert Montgomery, Myrna Loy, William GarganDirected by Clarence BrownThis is quite possibly the least known and seen all-star cast in film historyJohn Barrymore is strong, as usual, but his older brother Lionel, is the scene stealer in this film.Gable, just beginning his reign as the King of Hollywood, is almost unrecognizable in his pilot's outfit.Robert Montgomery manages to have scenes with the most co-stars in the picture, except for maybe John Barrymore.Helen Hayes is effective as the wife as far as that goes.Gable and Loy are husband and wife, but they never have a scene together.Clarence Brown, who has directed Garbo, was one of MGM's most romantic directors, always setting an atmosphere where love either triumphed or ended tragically.With this all-star cast and the story line and plot, it is a shame there is a shocking waste of talent.NIGHT FLIGHT would have been a better movie with the exact same script and director but without the all star cast. With all those people in it, we want them to have scenes together and play off each other like in DINNER AT EIGHT and the fact that they don't is distracting.* Special Footnote: -- There was to have been a scene in which Clark Gable jumped out of a plane at an altitude of 25,000 feet. The stuntman Jim Unger, who was to double for Clark, passed out at 20,000 feet from lack of oxygen and the shot never got made.BIOS:1. reviewText: For a 1933 production, this was well worth viewing.  Strong acting, wonderful flying sequences, rare story.  Very few "airplane models" as most of the flying was done in real airplanes, although over the Colorado Rockies and not the Andes.  Flying the mail at night and in all kinds of weather faced the same challenges in the US before World War II.  Also rare to see the two Barrymores in a movie together, as well as a young Clark Gable.  One interesting detail - the first thing one of the pilots did when he got back on the ground was to request a cigarette and smoked it while he was still in the cockpit.  The fabric and dope used on these old planes was extremely flammable, but at the time, everyone smoked.  Well worth it - as a great black and white movie and unique slice of flying history. M&M

reviewText: After the successful production of MGM's lavish 1932 star-studded classic "Grand Hotel," MGM's "Night Fight" tries to recapitulate on this success but falls short in this dramatization of pioneer aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupery's early days of airmail flights over the Andes.John Barrymore plays the general manager of an airline, operating in South America, a little too aggressively, and his brother Lionel Barrymore as the operations manager is the rule enforcing official. But unlike "Grand Hotel," where the major stars of the movie share common scenes, but in this movie the stars are not casted together. Helen Hayes is married to Clark Gable yet they never share the screen together. In fact Clark Gable is almost unrecognizable, and he is found usually sitting in the cockpit. Helen Hayes and Myrna Loy have performed splendidly in a limited role in this movie. Robert Montgomery is another pilot who has a more lively dialogue with Lionel Barrymore. MGM is known to make great all star classics in which stars get involved, we have seen them in "Grand Hotel," "China Seas," and "Dinner At Eight," but why they aren't too involved with each other in this movie. Why did MGM casted them together at great cost to the studios? The movie is essentially a two-man show.The movie is supported by a great music score and beautiful flight photography in the air. The aviation footage is adventurous enough, but if you really want to see an adventurous movie about risky flights over the Andes in South America, I would recommend "Only Angels Have Wings" where Howard Hawks pilots very risky and more adventurous flights. Flying in the early days of aviation is a daring, and very scary around the snow covered mountains especially when it is covered with thick fog. In this regard this movie is interesting.1.Grand Hotel2.Only Angels Have Wings3.Dinner at Eight (1933)4.China Seas
summary: A star studded classic from MGM

reviewText: Although not on the story quality of MGM's Grand Hotel or other similar All Star Casts, the many major stars, sets, story line, airplane make up for any loss of script or story line in this rarely seen MGM film from the Golden Age of Hollywood.  Highly recommended for those who love the older films of Hollywood when Stars had contracts with Studios, and their presence oftentimes made up for scripts not always at the top.  John Barrymore holds his own in this movie of many of the great MGM stars during this influential period of Hollywood's history.

reviewText: "Night Flight" is not the greatest film ever made, but it seems ground-breaking in many ways.  Clarence Brown's creative direction is modern for 1933, far more so than other films of that year.  While the script is weak, the visuals are breathtaking, and must have packed a whallup in 1933.  One of the most surprising elements of the film is Herbert Stothart's score.  From the title sequence on, the music seems far ahead of its time, in composition and in the presentation of the sound itself.  If I didn't know better, I'd think this movie was made in the late 30s.  Again, I don't know of another film that "sounds" like this from the period.  A lot of money spent, a great amount of creativity employed, and a fine early example of the "Selznick touch!"
summary: some amazing elements to this film
